context:
In the impeccably polished kitchen where Tessa met her fatal end through a deadly gas, Detective Winston starts his journey of dark secrets, questioning Penelope and Grace, a sharp‑witted woman,, the two prime suspects.
  
 

  Winston swept through Tessa's starkly white yet crimson-stained kitchen, pausing over the various chemicals laid across her dining table. The room smelled of cleaners, a scent that clashed with the stark reality of its circumstances - a tragic and untimely death. A photograph on the fridge captured his attention - an image of Tessa, alongside a tall, dark-haired woman who he recognized as Penelope, a local tarot reader.
  
 

  Later on, his investigations led him to the drains where he suspected Penelope's large chemical purchase from the day before had been dumped. The local authorities confirmed it. The incident was also marked by Penelope's unanticipated visit to Tessa's place during which no witness was there to mark her departure. Despite this, a CT-TV camera at the end of Tessa's street had picked up Penelope leaving just before the estimated time of Tessa's death, something that felt unusual given Tessa's friendly, social neighborhood ethos.
  
 

  Penelope's home struck him as a stark counterpoint to Tessa's clean, modern aesthetic. Her decor smacked of a dark gothic undertone, featuring cherubs and pentagrams. The display left no doubt about Penelope’s approximation towards medieval tarot readers and alchemists which was further solidified by her quirky ornaments and stacks of intimidating books.
  
 

  Winston pointed out a book lying open on a nearby table, which displayed disturbing diagrams and descriptions of different poisonous gases. 
  
 

  "What's this here?" Winston asked, pointing at it.
  
 

  "O-oh, I was...reading it for a character in my book," Penelope stammered.
  
 

  Shifting in her seat, Penelope added, "A character who thinks they can commit the perfect crime, leaving no traces."
  
 

  "Their own idea of justice, perhaps?" Winston ventured, aware of the calculated cryptic response.
  
 

  Penelope nodded, emphasis paving way to dread as Winston clarified,
  "A crime that might... involve poisonous gas?"
  
 

  Penelope’s fear manifested through her expressive features, propelling Winston to probe her further.
  
 

  "It appears that Tessa had found letters linking you with past offenses..." Winston began, only to be interrupted mid-sentence as Penelope braced herself.
  
 

  "She did confront me, yes. Said something about me having been involved in past crimes. I did not...," her voice quivered, trailing off.
  
 

  "You were seen arriving at Tessa's place that evening. But, oddly enough, nobody actually saw you leave...why do you suppose that is?" Winston asked, deliberately amplifying the tension.
  
 

  "Well, I... I was there to read her tarot that evening. I was alone in the kitchen while she was getting us some wine."
  
 

  "But still, no sightings of your departure?" Winston pressed.
  
 

  "I... It...," Penelope faltered, but Winston refrained from asking further questions. He pocketed his notepad before making his way to the exit. As he left, he caught a glimpse of a chemistry degree hanging by the door - a degree that censured the name Penelope on its title. This discovery validated the suspicions about her in-depth knowledge of chemistry and alchemy - fields possibly employed for darker purposes.
  
 

  Winston squinted over the rim of his empty coffee mug at the nervous officer seated across the table. Grace cleared her throat, uneasy under the direct and critical gaze of the grizzled detective.
  
 

  "So, Tessa's bakery... it was right smack in the middle of the expansion you proposed for your patrol zone, wasn't it?" Winston asked, pausing to lean back on his chair, "To my understanding, all other businesses in the area were highly cooperative. Was Tessa the only one resisting the expansion?"
  
 

  "Yes, sir." Grace said, her tone defensive. "And every time I tried to talk to Tessa about it, maybe cut a deal, she wasn't having it. She was the only stubborn holdout against my proposals."
  
 

  "I see." Winston scribbled a note on the paper in front of him, shielding it from view with a well-practiced arm block. "Dealing with hazardous materials... that's part of police training, right? You've taken classes for that?"
  
 

  Grace nodded. "Sure, we all have. Necessary for emergency situations."
  
 

  "Hmm. Have access to any of these dangerous substances?" Winston asked, his eyes flickering up from his notes.
  
 

  Grace puzzled over this question for a moment. "Well, yes. We have a secure storage for them. For certain operations."
  
 

  "Like poisonous gas," Winston said, as if discussing the weather. Grace hesitated and then nodded, a flicker of apprehension crossing her face.
  
 

  "Have any hobbies, Officer Grace?"
  
 

  "Um, reading, I suppose," she said, stiffening. "I always have a bunch of new thrillers and murder mysteries borrowed from the library."
  
 

  "What do you read?"
  
 

  Grace raised her eyebrows, almost startled. "Different stuff. But mostly thrillers, murder mysteries..."
  
 

  "Funny. Your co-workers mention seeing you engrossed in them quite often during breaks. Read them at your house too, for a book club, don't you?" Winston pursued, ignoring the slight flush that spread across Grace's cheeks. 
  
 

  "Well...yes," Grace admitted, nearly blushing. "We frequently meet up at my place to discuss the latest thriller."
  
 

  Downing the last dregs of his cold coffee, Winston pushed away from the table and stood to leave. "Well, Officer Grace," he said, pulling on his weathered leather jacket. "It seems there is much I need to ponder. We'll take it from here. Thank you for your time."
  
 

  He left Grace sitting in the cold interrogation room, her mind whirling.

When Joel's life was abruptly ended by a nunchaku at the local bowling alley, it is up to Detective Winston to interrogate the prime suspects: Rosemary and Mia, a sharp‑witted woman,, in this chilling game of strike or spare.
  
 

  Kneading the stub of his cigarette into the worn-out ashtray, Winston's gaze flitted between the photographs in front of him. A bowling alley, deserted, save for a solitary figure slumped over in the congealing slick of his own blood – the scene drenched in a chilling morbidity. 
  
 

  His suspect was Mia, a waitress at the bowling alley. The late shift was her domain; her eyes, always heavy-lidded with fatigue, had fallen on a familiar figure, Joel, numbingly often.   Fiddling with a small, old key on his desk, Winston’s thought went back to his first meeting with Mia. He had found the key while cleaning her table after an interview and asked her about it. Almost flippantly, she mentioned it was for a private mausoleum in the nearby cemetery. The location was within walking distance from her workplace, an old cemetery cloaked in a gloom that seemed centuries old. The eerie part was her odd ritual; post her shift, her coworkers attested to seeing her trudge towards the graveyard regularly, a private pilgrimage in the dead of night.
  
 

  Winston vividly remembered his surprise when he had found nunchaku, a pair of them, while searching Mia's home. The night visits to the cemetery coupled with the ominous presence of the martial arts weapon was undoubtedly unsettling. Unraveling further, he found out Mia had been practicing and honing her skills with the nunchaku at home, late into the night. For years, she had been devoted to martial arts, with a particular emphasis on the nunchaku, the significance of which crept up on him like a poisonous vine. Her gym was known for teaching the use of this weapon.
  
 

  "I suspect you're quite adept at swinging these," Winston had said to Mia, gesturing towards the nunchaku that lay on the table between them when he'd confronted her about it later. 
  
 

  Mia had smiled enigmatically, her eyes twinkling with the lethality of secrets untold. "Keep your eyes open, detective," she had replied, her voice a chilling sotto voce lingering between them, hang enough in the suffocating silence.
  
 

  His thoughts whirling, Winston stubbed out the last of his cigarette. The available evidence was yet to form a coherent story, but Mia was conspicuous. He had ventured into labyrinthian investigations before, but the mystery of Joel's murder felt like uncharted territory. Winston felt a shiver creep into his spine as he got ready for round two with Mia.
  
 

  Winston stepped into the dimly lit bowling alley, prowling between lanes like a panther on the hunt. An unusual place to be hammered to death, he thought, especially during the graveyard shift, but a good detective never questioned the chosen venues or the hour of the city's grim reaper. Winston surveyed the empty building, the only sound being that of his own boots echoing off the polished hardwood.
  
 

  The bartender, one Rosemary – if her nameplate could be trusted – was scrubbing down a countertop at the far corner of the bar. Winston walked over, took a seat on one of the bar stools and introduced himself. 
  
 

  "I hear you were working here the night Joel was killed," he mentioned, as he watched her movements. 
  
 

  Rosemary looked up, her face impassive, "Yes, that's true. It was my usual midnight shift, and Joel got murdered after we had closed down for the night. Wasn't much else to do."
  
 

  "You seem to have keys to this place," Winston noticed, spotting a set of keys on the counter. 
  
 

  "Yes, I do, for closing hours," she replied, sliding the keys back into her jeans pocket.
  
 

  He continued his questions, "I understand you practice martial arts, Rosemary?"
  
 

  For the first time, Rosemary stopped her cleaning and smiled, "Yes, that's right. In fact, I work out regularly at a martial arts gym. Nunchaku workshops are my favorite," she added, her eyes twinkling with something akin to pride.
  
 

  Winston nodded, imparting no judgement on her preferred pastime. 
  
 

  Suddenly, a glint at the corner of the room caught his attention. A collection of weaponry displayed on a wall. Upon closer look, he recognized various martial arts weapons, including a pair of nunchaku.
  
 

  “My father was a big fan of martial arts. He left me his collection," explained Rosemary, noticing his interest. "In fact, the nunchaku you see hanging on the wall is part of my personal collection."
  
 

  As Winston stood up to leave, he turned to Rosemary, "Did you know Joel well?"
  
 

  She hesitated for a moment, her eyes downcast, "Joel... he was a good friend. He always wanted to help. And he was the one person who could save me from this terrible debt I'm wrestling with. But to my despair, he... he said no when I asked him for a loan."
  
 

  As Winston exited the empty bowling alley, he couldn't help but mull over Rosemary's last words. This was shaping up to be a long investigation, a fact he was all too aware of as he walked into the piercing chill of the night cityscape.

In the mystifying quiet of a mosque, Isabella was found lifeless, a nunchaku the lone cause, casting Detective Winston into a whirlwind investigation with suspects Madison, a sharp‑witted woman, and Richard at the heart of the mystery.
  
 

  Detective Winston was in his office, pouring over the facts of the Isabella case. Isabella was a young woman murdered in a mosque with a pair of nunchaku. Her case was sent to him because not only was the method of murder unusual but the strange behavior she'd reported was disconcerting.
  
 

  Isabella had reported suspicious activity to the authorities, claiming an acquaintance named Madison was acting out of sorts. The name Madison was ringing alarm bells for Winston. The police had already questioned her regarding a theft, and now, with Isabella's murder, he felt the need to dig deeper.
  
 

  Winston knocked on the door of Madison's small home, case files in hand. She was a hairdresser by trade, known to be a fan of martial arts movies, placing Bruce Lee as her idol, and had a knack for practicing martial arts moves at home. She had purchased nunchaku recently.  
  
 

  Winston was greeted with a jovial smile when he arrived, and once pleasantries were exchanged, his questions began.
  
 

  “I noticed a uniform in that bag by your door,” Winston nodded towards the corner of the room. “You do martial arts?”
  
 

  “Sure do,” she replied cheerfully. “Nothing like a little kick and a punch after a long day, especially after watching a good martial arts movie.”
  
 

  Winston watched her closely but Madison seemed to only speak the truth. “Did you ever take martial arts classes?”
  
 

  Madison chuckled, “Does high school count? I took it for a few years then. I was a Bruce Lee in the making.”
  
 

  He took a deep breath and continued, “What about your family, Madison?” Winston asked, trying to dig into her background. 
  
 

  Madison shrugged. “Well detective, it's as erratic as the weather these days. Speaking of which, I do believe we are in for some rain later today."
  
 

  Feeling slightly exasperated, Winston decided to prod a bit more. "And your love life, Madison?" he asked. 
  
 

  "Oh, it's like 'Gone With The Wind'," she replied, winking at him. "An epic which suddenly disappears. Like any good movie, wouldn't you agree, Winston?"
  
 

  He decided to tread lightly. “You ever practice with nunchaku?”
  
 

  Madison’s gaze never wavered, “Oh, sure. Bought a pair recently. They came in handy when Isabella tried taking my TV. Those are some nice detective notes you've got there around a theft, happened a few days ago, isn't it? The police already asked me about those."
  
 

  As Winston left Madison's home, he was left with a feeling of uncertainty. There was much to unravel about this peculiar woman, and he still couldn’t shake off the uneasy feeling of her jovial exterior that hid a string of suspicious facts. Isabella might have been gone, but Winston was determined to uncover the truth for her sake.
  
 

  Winston eyed the austere environment of the mosque, draped in silence and shadows. As he looked at this deserted place of worship, he thought of the vibrant Isabella, now lying lifeless.
  
 

  Remembering his conversations with Isabella's friends, he couldn't help but recall them saying how determined she was to escape Richard for good. Isabella's friends had mentioned her to him - how she told them she intended to finally break free from Richard permanently.
  
 

  He decided to talk to Richard, a local waiter who had been working at the mosque during those deserted, deadly hours that took Isabella's life.
  
 

  Richard stood by the main entryway, enduring the barrage of lights and unfamiliar faces. Winston recognized him from his not-so-distant encounter with the law - a case of domestic violence involving him and Isabella.
  
 

  "Evening, Richard," Winston started, extending a friendly hand. "Been working here long?"
  
 

  "Few months, sir," Richard replied, his voice steady. "Only serve the occasional visitor during the day. I was alone yesterday. No one else was here."
  
 

  Winston nodded, making a mental note of Richard's presence at the mosque during the time of Isabella's murder. "I've seen you before. A martial arts class, wasn't it?"
  
 

  Richard's gaze flickered with surprise before he recovered, his professional mask back in place. "Yes. Same class as Isabella."
  
 

  Winston recalled seeing Richard in that martial arts class, practicing nunchaku - the same weapon that had ended Isabella's life. And not too long ago, he had seen him at the local sports equipment store, purchasing a set of nunchaku.
  
 

  "Quite a skill you've got there," Winston continued, keeping his voice casual. "Heard you and Isabella trained together."
  
 

  Richard sighed, his gaze flicked towards the mosque's silent dome. "Yeah, we both were there. Couldn't seem to get away from each other.”
  
 

  "I'm sure," Winston agreed. Neighbors had reported frequently hearing the couple arguing, their quarrels escalating in intensity. "How was Isabella doing?"
  
 

  Richard paused, his brow furrowed. "She... She was... planning to leave."
  
 

  "Leave?" Winston asked, knowing that Isabella had finally decided to break free from Richard permanently. She had even confided in her friends about her escape plans and purchased a ticket for a one-way trip out of the country.
  
 

  "Yes..." Richard's voice was barely audible. "Leave me. Leave everything."
  
 

  With that, Winston thanked Richard and turned to leave, his thoughts spinning around the tragic tale of Isabella, her life brutally ended in this quiet mosque she had formerly sought peace.

"It always upset me," she further admitted her thoughts, letting Winston understand the volatile mentor-protege relationship dynamics.
  
 

  Winston nodded, storing this important information about the dynamics between Paige and Renee. "I have found out from the delivery company that a flamethrower was delivered to this workshop recently. Was it yours? The one you ordered?"
  
 

  "Yes, that's correct," Paige replied, her face unchanging. "You see, I work in special effects. I deal with all sorts of contraptions, including flamethrowers. They're not as deadly as they seem, you know? Only in the wrong hands..."
  
 

  It seemed like Paige was positioning herself just within the edge of suspicion, but Winston kept his thoughts to himself, a stoic expression fixed on his face. He then asked about Paige's closeness with the desert, a quick detour from her workshop. 
  
 

  "Oh, it's easily accessible. I often take a walk to clear my head," she replied, "And Renee knew about my frequent trips there, that's why it wasn't unusual for her when I told her I wanted to show her something in the desert."
  
 

  Paige's love for Renee was well known and she wasn't ready to hide it when asked. "She was special to me, you know. But she never showed up to see what I planned. The next thing I know, she was dead."
  
 

  Feeling he had enough for the moment, Winston decided to end the conversation. Among the many things he had gathered, a fact that stuck to him was the requested flamethrower, seen in Paige's possession a few days ago, was also the murder weapon used in this case, delivered right at Paige's workshop.
  
 

  As Winston was leaving, Paige's gaze followed him. She had a look of a woman caught in a tale of true obsession.
  
 

  Winston parked his car in front of the coffee shop. The afternoon was calm and dry, typical of a day in the desert.
  "Hannah." He called to the barista working behind the counter.
  
 

  "Yes sir, what can I get you?" She looked up with a plastered service smile that Winston had seen more often than he'd like to admit.
  
 

  "Coffee, black," he added.
  
 

  Hannah was usually a woman of few words. It was already known in the café that Hannah, although a people person during work hours, preferred solitude outside of work. She was somewhat enigmatic, leaving work as soon as her shift ended without any explanation about her after-work plans. It was a habit she diligently stuck to, against curious coworkers who often loiter around longer.
  
 

  "Winston, aren't you?" She handed over the coffee, her facial expression gave away nothing. She had a breed of indifference that he found puzzling.
  
 

  "Yeah, you remember." He toasted his coffee cup, looking at the foam art on its surface.
  
 

  Rumor has it that Hannah had been spotted frequenting a local pawn shop on her way from work. Curiously, after one of her visits, a flamethrower was found missing from the shop - the owner had confirmed it himself, ruffling through the shop inventory in disbelief. A particular stock draw from the shop should technically be tagged a coincidence and yet, here he was.
  
 

  "So, how'd you end up here?" Winston decided to put out some line, in search of a bite.
  
 

  "Needed a job, this did me good," she stated curtly, keeping it decidedly professional.
  
 

  "I hear you gotta get fire safety certification to keep the espresso machines running and avoid mishaps. That true?" He ventured further.
  
 

  "Yeah, mandatory stuff." She added, the impenetrable exterior still intact.
  
 

  "That's neat, handy skills I reckon." He sipped his coffee, testing the waters.
  
 

  That's when he remembered the rumors – Hannah had been arrested for a theft charge. Worse yet, she was found guilty and now, a court date next week awaiting sentencing. It all seemed to tie back to an unfortunate event in the desert involving an individual named Renee, who had testified against Hannah in court. Not just a common run-in-the-mill victim, but linked to Hannah with a web of unknown connections.
  
 

  "What time do you get off work?" He asked, catching her off guard.
  
 

  "I...like to go straight home." She fumbled her words. The confession about her arrest seemed to take the wind out of her sails.
  
 

  After a small chat about the dry weather, Winston mentioned he was headed to the pawn shop down the road, on the trail of the missing flamethrower, leaving a hint of a departing farewell. She visibly winced, although she recovered quickly, her unusually bright eyes watched him with a hint of alarm as he walked out.
  
 

  She turned to the wall clock as soon as the shop door jingled shut - the end of her shift almost due. Winston absorbed this behavior, letting his gaze linger for one more moment before setting off.

Along with that, he also took note of another change in her appearance on Monday - the color of her contacts. She was seen wearing blue contacts, unlike the green ones she was wearing during the Wednesday meeting.
  
 

  Victoria was a special effects expert, especially adept at managing flamethrowers, probably a reason for the flamethrower request at her special effects workshop. Something Victoria had mentioned stood out to him, her desire to demonstrate something in the desert to Renee, her mentor.
  
 

  Upon returning from the desert to Victoria's workshop, the tech area was filled with different props and gadgets, all related to special effects. Among all, the flamethrower that she had requested stood out, it was identical to the one she was spotted with a few days back.
  
 

  Tired and deep in thought, he took some quiet time to contemplate his findings, particularly about the chilling fact - Victoria was the last person to be seen with Renee before she went missing.
  
 

  As always, Winston's face remained mask-like, revealing nothing as he continued to probe and understand, focusing solely on gathering the facts of the chaotic mosaic before him. He knew there were many pieces yet to be put into place before the picture could begin to make sense.
  
 

  Winston gazed over the desert horizon, letting his eyes rest on what felt like an infinite sea of sand. It was here where Renee's body was found, thoroughly torched, origins of which was thought to be a flamethrower. 
  
 

  He headed away from the scene, his mind whirling with questions and concerns, to conduct his next interview. His destination was a well-known cafe at the edge of town.
  
 

  Marianne, the barista, had a strange calmness about her, despite being awaiting her punishment next week after being found guilty of theft. She didn’t flinch when she saw officer Winston approach - instead, she graciously offered him a cup of Joe. Around her, there was no evidence of anyone else's presence.
  
 

  “Hello Marianne,” Winston made idle chat, “It must get pretty hot back here in the summers.”
  
 

  “Surely does, but we’ve got it under control,” Marianne replied, sipping her coffee, “We've all done a thorough fire safety course.”
  
 

  Winston nodded and decided to change the subject. “I heard you've recently visited the pawn shop and there seems to be a flamethrower missing after your visit”
  
 

  “Sometimes, yeah, I shop there. Good old stuff comes cheap,” Marianne replied casually, not giving away any signs of panic.

  “Can't recall,” Marianne quickly replied, her tone betraying nothing.
  
 

  Winston shifted gears again, “Sounds like you have some travel plans? A solo road trip...”
  
 

  Marianne shrugged, “I keep hearing about this desert route, figured I might give it a shot.”

  Before he could finish, Marianne held up a hand, “Renee, wasn’t it? She testified against me in court if you weren’t aware. Sad news for sure.”
  
 

  “Indeed,” Winston nodded solemnly, “Indeed it is.” He finished his coffee and stood up to leave. “Good luck with your punishment next week, Marianne. See you around.”

context:
In the lavish surroundings of a luxury restaurant, Renee's life was cut brutally short by barbed wire; now, Detective Winston must unravel the tangled suspects, Claire and Ella, a female,.
  
 

  Winston found himself in the bustling metropolis, drawn by a callous crime that had surprised even him. The victim, Renee, was a rising star in the music scene and her death had shocked everyone. At the top of the suspect list was Ella, a devoted groupie of what seemed to be the rival band.
  
 

  As he stepped onto the stage of what had previously been the sight of the unfortunate event, Winston remembered what led him here. A music gala where Renee’s band had triumphed and Ella’s favorite, struggled. 
  
 

  Winston recalled how Ella had not taken this well. She was vocal, very vocal about her displeasure. The public declaration of her resentment - just another peculiar thing about the woman. This incident especially struck Winston because in all his discussions with Ella's friends, none of them ever mentioned meeting the band members, providing more peculiarity to Ella's obsession. 
  
 

  "Meeting Ella for the second time, is it?" the stage manager asked. Winston nodded. Questions about her past had prompted more questions than answers. Publically, Ella was known to be biased against Renee's culture. Subject to discrimination lawsuits filed by those she regularly chose to isolate.
  
 

  Getting into the intricacies of Ella’s life had been more complicated than catching a spider in a hurricane. She never gave a straight answer about her activities in her free time, a fact that had earned her some scrutiny.
  
 

  "Constant red flags with this one," Winston mused to himself. Ella had a knack for privacy. She left the room whenever she received a phone call. Never invited her friends to the band's concerts. Always arrived alone.
  
 

  On the other hand, she was known for learning survival skills from online sources. Owned a private collection of survival tools at her home, where the infamous barbed wire was reportedly found. The same barbed wire, as was later confirmed, used against an intruder some months back. 
  
 

  As he was leaving, Winston got a call from a local store clerk who claimed to have sold a roll of barbed wire to Ella the day before the horrific event.
  
 

  “All evidence points to her,” the store clerk had said.
  
 

  “Nothing is for certain yet,” Winston had firmly replied. He knew the importance to avoid jumping to conclusions, let the evidence guide the investigation. With those thoughts, he tucked away his notepad and decided to keep a closer eye on Ella. The ball game was just starting to get interesting. His aim was to do whatever it took to ensure that this case reached a fair pitch.
  
 

  As Winston cruised up to the crime scene, he took a moment to appreciate the opulence of the luxury restaurant. A grand piano player in the lobby, exotic flora, and a gourmet menu, it had it all. A lady, Claire as he would come to know, was sitting outside the restaurant in her car. She was shaking, clearly upset, her eyes teary and red.
  
 

  "I suppose you're Claire," Winston guessed, peering through the passenger side window. 
  
 

  "Yes," she sniffed. "I work here and in that place..." she pointed feebly towards the towering construction site in the near distance. "Merely a secretary during the day, and a skilled gardener during my time off, never a scratch from the barbed wire that fences my garden." 
  
 

  "Seems like you've got your hands full," Winston remarked, eyeing the construction site. "That's a lot of barbed wire over there."
  
 

  "Yes..." she said, "but I'm used to handling barbed wire. We've got some fencing my garden at home too."
  
 

  "I heard you have keys to all sections of this restaurant," asked Winston.
  
 

  "Yes, I do," Claire nodded, "the management insists we keep everything secure, and since I work here, they trust me with the keys."
  
 

  "Why were you at the restaurant today, Claire?" He asked, looking closely at the woman in front of him. 
  
 

  "I usually work at the restaurant during lunch hours," Claire responded. "Today was no different."
  
 

  "Strange circumstances today, though..." Winston said. "Did you know Renee was planning to file a report about some huge financial disparities at the restaurant?"
  
 

  Claire squirmed a bit at his words. "I heard something about it," she mumbled. "But it's only whispers. Renee believed there was a thief... that there was someone embezzling money from the restaurant."
  
 

  "And she thought that person was you, didn't she?" Winston questioned.
  
 

  Claire's face turned whiter than it already was. "I...I..." was all she could choke out. 
  
 

  "She had evidence, Claire," Winston continued, taking the report out of his bag. "She'd traced back all the missing funds to your bank account." He waived it in the air between them. "She was about to expose you, wasn't she?"
  
 

  "Yes," she whispered, almost inaudibly, confirming her role in the embezzlement.
  
 

  Winston left Claire in her car, lost in her thoughts. Puzzles to piece together, he thought to himself, getting in his car and heading back to the precinct.

Isaac, with his whistleblowing nature, had recently acquired extensive evidence on a tax evasion scheme. This scheme was alleged to be run by none other than Milton.
  
 

  Winston spotted Milton, the robust man in his sixties and owner of the building, emerging from the fitness center. An overcast of suspicion hung over Milton as he owned several other buildings in the area, all implicated in his alleged tax evasion scandal.
  
 

  Revealing his badge, Winston introduced himself, "Detective Winston. I'd like to ask a few questions." Milton, nonchalant as always, simply answered, "About Isaac?"
  
 

  "Yeah... You knew him well?"
  
 

  Milton adjusted the strap of his shotgun before answering, "He was a tenant. That's all."
  
 

  Winston furrowed his brows, "That shotgun - it's legal!"
  
 

  "Indeed," Milton declared, "I even passed the required training course. The local authorities granted me a license."
  
 

  Winston's eyes darted to the keys in the man's hand, "I see you also have keys to the gym."
  
 

  "It's my property, Detective," Milton responded dismissively.
  
 

  Winston sighed, unfazed by Milton's audacity, "It's undisputed that the gym is never locked yet Isaac was alone last night. He had potential evidence that could have sent you to prison, Milton."
  
 

  "So?" Milton's face revealed no fear and no hint of adversity.
  
 

  This reaction gnawed at Winston as he returned to his car. Thoughts of Isaac's murder - the shotgun wound matching the one Milton regularly carried, Milton's unfazed demeanor despite the possible charges, and Milton's evident firearms training - swarmed his mind. As he mulled over these facts, he made a mental note to delve deeper into Isaac's evidence - the potential key to exposing Milton's illicit activities and ensuring justice.
  
 

  Winston squinted his eyes, scanning the familiar hustle and bustle of the fitness center. The crime scene of Isaac's murder was abnormal, the contrast of violence against the backdrop of health and vitality. 
  
 

  Dodging a stray basketball, he made his way to the bench where Alice and Isaac used to workout together regularly. Alice had a spotless record with the fitness center - seemed she had never missed a month of membership dues.
  
 

  As he advanced, he remembered a fact shared by Alice's friends. They had alluded to how Alice sneakily mentioned fight club every Tuesday night, a pattern they had quickly noticed.
  
 

  Spotting the middle-aged woman, he strode toward Alice. Her movements were graceful as she pulled down the levels, her muscles contracting with every repetition. She had been in the military, particularly in a special weapons unit where her training with shotguns had given her an edge. Her fitness regime bore witness to that, and she knew her way around weapons- the shotgun she recently purchased was just a testament to that.
  
 

  "Hello Alice," he initiated the conversation. He knew patience was key in such delicate interrogations, especially with suspects like Alice.
  
 

  "Oh, Winston, what an unexpected surprise!" Alice's face lit up with genuine surprise, her eyes shifting to the shotgun propped at the corner of the bench, its presence undeniable.
  
 

  Discarding any pleasantries, Winston moved to the crux of the matter. "Isaac trained right here didn’t he, you guys used to train together?"
  
 

  Alice gave a small nod, memories flickering in her eyes. Winston observed her, recognizing a trace of melancholy. Alice’s dulcet voice broke the silence. "Yes...we had a sort of routine together."
  
 

  He glanced at her bruised knuckles appreciatively, a new patch of purple catching his attention. Her friends had mentioned Alice's weekly fight club rendezvous every Tuesday night. The tough soldier, habituated to the brutality of the fight club, would invariably return home every Wednesday morning nursing fresh battle sores.
  
 

  Alice was a puzzle piece in a complex jigsaw puzzle. An aunt, a loyal fitness center member, a fighter, and undoubtedly an experienced shotgun user due to her military background. Her every Tuesday night fights stood out starkly against her normal routine. She was a conundrum tightly bound by her routine, fitness center membership, military background, and her recent shotgun purchase.
  
 

  "You know Winston...Isaac was the only family I had left," Alice mused, her thoughts clearly going down a memory lane, her fingers tracing her recent shotgun casually. The shotgun she had recently purchased was now in her possession. With these words, she abruptly stood up, signaled the trainer for her next routine, leaving Winston to join the dots of the puzzle she represented in this murder mystery.

In fact, a tenant had once mentioned that Amelia regularly shops for coats and ties at funeral shops.
  
 

  Winston spotted a shotgun in a corner, a disturbing sight considering it was the same type specified in the coroner's report for Isaac's death. It was an intriguing piece of evidence, considering Amelia owns the shotgun.
  
 

  Their conversation veered into various topics, with Amelia highlighting his passion for reading. His bookshelf was lined with an extensive collection of books on death rituals from around the world - yet another proof of his peculiar interests.

  As Winston left the fitness center, he pondered on his findings. He was confident that the tax evasion evidence would be enough to send Amelia to jail, but for now, only time would tell. It was just another day on the job for Winston. As for Amelia, his fate hung in the balance.
  
 

  Detective Winston studied the scene: shattered glass, blood splatter, and scattered workout equipment telling a silent story. The fitness center wasn't the usual type of crime scene he found himself in. He sighed deeply and headed over to his prime suspect: Alice.
  
 

  Alice was just a stone's throw away from the crime scene. Staring blankly with pale, emotionless eyes. In her hand, a shotgun; paperwork indicating a fresh purchase tucked within its case, valid purchase documents all checked out at the base.
  
 

  Winston approached Alice cautiously and asked, "You know Isaac's workout routine, correct? The list of Isaac's routines you've given us earlier... it matches the information we gathered. You both were here all the time."

  Winston's eyes flickered to the shotgun slackly rested in Alice's lap. "Been a while since I've seen a lady with a new piece like this."
  
 

  Alice was quick to correct him, "Not to boast, Winston, but I've been handling such arms ever since my military days."
  
 

  Despite the grim predicament, Winston could tell Alice was trying to be cooperative. She was calm, composed; despite the whole flare-up. He moved on to the next line of questioning, "Your son... he interacted often with Isaac?"
  
 

  Alice appeared apprehensive before finally admitting, "Recently, yes... He told me Isaac threatened him. Isaac... he acted aggressively towards my boy often."
  
 

  "Interesting," Winston stammered, not wanting to press Alice too hard. He asked a softer question to lighten the mood, "You often workout together then?"
  
 

  Alice looked surprised and retorted mockingly, "Is it that weird? We were the members of the same fitness center after all."
  
 

  Before Winston could continue his questioning, he was handed a document by one of his officers. It read Isaac’s name and the note of a restraining order filed against him by a previous ex-partner. It seemed complicating factors always came in multiples in cases such as this.
  
 

  Without keeping Alice in the dark, he disclosed the information with her, “A restraining order, and a school expulsion due to fighting incidents... Isaac seemed to have some rough patches in the past, huh?”
  
 

  Alice turned her head and acknowledged Winston's statement with a slight nod, her lips sealed shut.
  
 

  Winston wasn't sure why, but he felt the need to reassure her and said, "We're in this together, Alice. We'll figure it out. If Isaac was threatening your son, then we can't overlook any facet of the situation."
